tika-vin04t0:0_0: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
tika-vin04t0:100_1: If a monk is having a new blanket made, he should use two parts of entirely black wool, a third part of white, and a fourth part of brown.
tika-vin04t0:100_2: If he has a new blanket made without using two parts of entirely black wool, a third part of white, and a fourth part of brown, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:101_0: The training rule on six years
tika-vin04t0:102_1: If a monk has a new blanket made without using a new blanket made, must keep it for six years, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:104_1: If a monk is having a sitting-blanket made, he must incorporate a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket in order to make it ugly.
tika-vin04t0:104_2: If he has a new sitting-blanket made without incorporating a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:106_1: If he is traveling, but he may receive it if he wishes. He may receive it if he wishes. He may receive it if he regards it himself no longer than 40 kilometers.
tika-vin04t0:106_2: If he carries it further than that, even if there is no one else to carry it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:107_0: The training rule on getting wool washed
tika-vin04t0:108_1: If a monk gets an unrelated nun to wash, dye, or comb wool, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:10_0: to the observance-day procedure and the monks who should be present have arrived.
tika-vin04t0:110_1: If a monk takes, gets someone else to take, or consents to gold and silver being deposited for him, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:111_0: The training rule on trading with money,
tika-vin04t0:112_0: If a monk trades with money in various ways, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:114_0: If a monk barters in various ways, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:115_0: The second sub-chapter on silk is finished.
tika-vin04t0:117_0: If he keeps it for more than two or three days, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:118_0: The training rule on fewer than five mends
tika-vin04t0:119_1: If a monk exchanges an almsbowl with fewer than five mends for a new almsbowl, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:119_2: That monk should relinquish that almsbowl to a gathering of monks; he should give away, a gathering of monks; he should remember it. Moreover, they should have attained the bowl; he should be lost their robe. This is the should be declared.
tika-vin04t0:121_1: The tonics allowable for sick monks—
tika-vin04t0:121_2: When ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and salt—should be used from storage for at most seven days, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:122_0: The training rule on rainy-season robes
tika-vin04t0:123_1: that a monk who has lost his rainy-season robe, may look for a rainy-season robe, if he seeks the rainy-season robe. When there is a half-month left, he may sew it and then wear it.
tika-vin04t0:123_2: If he goes looking for cloth for his rainy-season robe when there is a month left of the hot season, or if he sews a rainy-season robe, then when there is more than a half-month left, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:124_0: The training rule on taking back robe-cloth
tika-vin04t0:125_1: If a monk himself gives a robe to a monk, but then, in anger, takes it back or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:126_0: The training rule on asking for thread
tika-vin04t0:127_0: If a monk himself asks for thread, and then has weavers weave him robe-cloth, having it woven, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:128_0: The long training rule on weavers
tika-vin04t0:129_1: ‘A male or female householder is having robe-cloth woven by weavers for an unrelated monk and, without first being invited, that monk goes to weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants what has been brought for me, and that robe-cloth is well guarded and well proclaimed, for me. Hopefully we can see that monk,
tika-vin04t0:129_2: then, in saying that and afterwards giving them a small gift, even if it is only a bit of almsfood, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:12_0: to investigate the Vajjis, and don’t make a statement.’
tika-vin04t0:131_1: if he receives the rainy-season robe when there are ten days left to the Kattika full moon that ends the first rainy-season residence and then store it until he haste it received. He may then store it until the end of the robe season.
tika-vin04t0:131_2: If he stores it beyond that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:132_0: The training rule on what is risky
tika-vin04t0:133_1: After observing the rainy season, the rainy-season residence out that are considered risky and dangerous. After observing the Kattika full moon that ends the rainy season, a monk who is staying in such a dwelling may store one of his three robes in an inhabited area, if he so desires, so long as he has a reason for staying apart from that robe.
tika-vin04t0:133_2: If he stays apart from it beyond that, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:134_0: The training rule on what is intended
tika-vin04t0:135_0: If a monk diverts to himself material support that he knows was intended for the Sangha, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:136_0: The third sub-chapter on almsbowls is finished.
tika-vin04t0:137_0: “Venerables, the thirty rules on relinquishment and confession have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:137_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:13_0: Becoming they had taught and pointed out the craft of the Sangha of monks for the full ordination, for the reciter of the Monastic Code.
tika-vin04t0:140_0: Venerables, these ninety-two rules on confession have been recited
tika-vin04t0:143_0: and he lies in full awareness, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:144_0: The training rule on abusive speech
tika-vin04t0:145_0: and he has laid down the section.
tika-vin04t0:146_0: The training rule on malicious talebearing
tika-vin04t0:147_0: It is due to those other monks.
tika-vin04t0:148_0: The training rule on memorizing the Teaching
tika-vin04t0:149_0: If a monk who is not fully ordained instructs for the person who is not fully ordained to memorize the Teaching, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:150_0: The first rule, the training rule on the same sleeping place,
tika-vin04t0:151_0: If a monk lay down more than two or three nights in the same sleeping place as a person who is not fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:152_0: The second training rule on the same sleeping place
tika-vin04t0:153_0: If a monk lay down in the same sleeping place as a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:155_1: If a monk gives a teaching of more than five or six sentences to a woman, except in the presence of a man who understands, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:156_0: The training rule on telling truthfully
tika-vin04t0:157_0: If a monk truthfully tells a person who is not fully ordained of a superhuman quality, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:158_0: The training rule on telling about what is grave
tika-vin04t0:159_1: If a monk tells a person who is not fully ordained about a monk’s grave offense, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:15_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
tika-vin04t0:15_1: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should do the observance-day procedure, it should recite the Monastic Code.
tika-vin04t0:160_0: The training rule on digging the earth
tika-vin04t0:161_0: If a monk digs the earth, or has it dug, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:162_0: The first sub-chapter on lying is finished.
tika-vin04t0:164_0: If he destroys the plants, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:165_0: The training rule on evasive speech
tika-vin04t0:166_0: If he speaks evasively and harasses, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:168_0: If he complains about or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:169_0: The first rule, the training rule on furniture,
tika-vin04t0:16_0: What is the preliminary duty of the Sangha?
tika-vin04t0:16_1: ʻVenerables, I’ll recite the Monastic Code to one who is reciting that.
tika-vin04t0:16_2: Anyone who has committed an offense should reveal it, but if they remain silent. If I’d say they wouldn’t have a protector of the offense, I’ll play it even though it is pure.’
tika-vin04t0:16_3: Just as one who is asked individually responds, so too, the gathering is made up to three times in this kind of gathering.
tika-vin04t0:16_4: If a monk remembers an offense but doesn’t reveal it when an announcement is made up to the third time, he is lying in full awareness.
tika-vin04t0:16_5: Venerables, in full awareness is called an obstacle by the Buddha. That monk remembers and has committed the worst kind of offense, and who should reveal it. He’s reveal it when he’s comfortable, put out the remainder, and make amends for an offense.
tika-vin04t0:170_1: If a monk takes a bed, a bench, a mattress, or a stool belonging to the Sangha and puts it outside or has it put outside, and he then departs without putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:171_0: The second rule, the second training rule on furniture,
tika-vin04t0:172_1: If a monk puts out bedding in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, or has it put out, and he then departs without putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:174_1: If, in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, a monk arranges his sleeping place in a way that encroaches on a monk that he knows arrived there before him, with the intention that anyone who feels crowded will leave, and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession.’
tika-vin04t0:175_0: The training rule on throwing out from throwing out,
tika-vin04t0:176_1: If a monk, in anger, throws a monk out of a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, or has him thrown out, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:177_0: The training rule on upper stories
tika-vin04t0:178_1: If a monk sits down or lies down on a bed or a bench with detachable legs on an upper story in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:179_0: The training rule on large dwellings
tika-vin04t0:17_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:180_1: If a monk is building a large dwelling, then standing where there are no cultivated plants, he may apply two or three courses of roofing material, taking it as far as the doorcase and using it for fixing the door and for treating the window openings, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:181_0: The training rule on containing living beings
tika-vin04t0:182_1: If a monk pours water that he knows contains living beings onto grass or clay, or has it poured, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:183_0: The second sub-chapter on plants is finished.
tika-vin04t0:184_0: The training rule on the instruction
tika-vin04t0:185_0: If a monk who has been agreed upon, but he does not instruct the nuns, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:186_0: The training rule on gone down
tika-vin04t0:187_0: which has been agreed upon, and if a monk instructs the nuns after sunset, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:188_0: The training rule on nuns’ dwelling places
tika-vin04t0:189_1: If a monk goes to the nuns’ dwelling place and then instructs them, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:189_2: This is the appropriate occasion: a nun is sick.’”
tika-vin04t0:190_0: The training rule on worldly gain
tika-vin04t0:191_0: If a monk says, “May the senior monks please instruct the nuns,” and he instructs them, then he commits an offense entailing confession.’
tika-vin04t0:192_0: The training rule on giving robe-cloth
tika-vin04t0:193_0: If a monk gives robe-cloth to an unrelated nun, except if it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:194_0: The training rule on sewing robes
tika-vin04t0:195_0: and if a monk sews a robe for an unrelated nun, or has one sewn, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:196_0: The training rule on being inspired
tika-vin04t0:197_1: If a monk travels by appointment with a nun, even just to the next village, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:197_2: This is the appropriate occasion: the road is considered risky and dangerous and should be traveled with a group.’”
tika-vin04t0:198_0: The training rule on boarding boats
tika-vin04t0:199_1: If a monk boards a boat by appointment with a nun, either to go upstream or downstream, except for the purpose of crossing, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:200_0: The training rule on had prepared
tika-vin04t0:201_1: If a monk eats almsfood knowing that a nun had it prepared, except if the householder had already intended to prepare it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:202_0: The training rule on sitting in private,
tika-vin04t0:203_0: If a monk sits down in private alone with a nun, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:204_0: The third sub-chapter on the instruction is finished.
tika-vin04t0:205_0: The training rule on alms-meals at public guesthouses
tika-vin04t0:206_0: If he is not sick, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:207_0: The rule, the training rule on group meals, is finished
tika-vin04t0:208_1: ‘If a monk eats in a group, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:208_2: These are the appropriate occasions: he is sick; it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes; he is traveling; he is traveling by boat; it is a big occasion; it is a meal given by an ascetic.’”
tika-vin04t0:209_0: The training rule on eating a meal before another,
tika-vin04t0:20_0: There are four rules on expulsion for recitation.
tika-vin04t0:210_1: ‘If a monk eats a meal before another, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:210_2: These are the appropriate occasions: he is sick; it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes; he is sick.’”
tika-vin04t0:212_1: If a monk approaches a family and is invited to take pastries or baked goods, he may accept two or three bowlfuls if he wishes.
tika-vin04t0:212_2: If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:212_3: If he accepts two or three bowlfuls, he should take it away and share it with the monks.
tika-vin04t0:213_0: The first rule, the training rule on invitation
tika-vin04t0:214_1: But a monk who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, and then eats staple or non-staple food that is not left over, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:215_0: The second training rule on invitation
tika-vin04t0:216_1: If a monk invites a monk, whom he knows has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, to eat staple or non-staple food that is not left over, saying, “Here, monk, eat,” aiming to criticize him, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:217_0: The training rule on eating at the wrong time,
tika-vin04t0:218_0: If a monk eats staple or non-staple food at the wrong time, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:220_1: If a monk eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:221_0: The training rule on fine foods,
tika-vin04t0:222_1: But any of these kinds of fine foods are present, such as
tika-vin04t0:222_2: ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and milk.
tika-vin04t0:222_3: If a monk who is not sick eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:223_0: The training rule on tooth cleaners
tika-vin04t0:224_0: When a monk eats food that has not been given, except for water and tooth cleaners, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:225_0: The fourth sub-chapter on eating is finished.
tika-vin04t0:226_0: The training rule on naked ascetics
tika-vin04t0:227_1: If a monk gives staple or non-staple food to a naked ascetic, to a male wanderer, or to a female wanderer with his own hands, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:228_0: The training rule on sending away
tika-vin04t0:229_1: If a monk says to a monk, “Come, let’s go to the village or town for alms,” and then, whether he has had food given to him or not, sends him away, saying, “Go away, I’m not comfortable talking or sitting with you, but only if I talk and sit by myself,” and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:22_1: If a monk, after taking on the monks’ training and way of life, without first renouncing the training and revealing his weakness, has sexual intercourse, even with a female animal, he is expelled and excluded from the community.
tika-vin04t0:231_0: If a monk sits down intruding on a lustful couple, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:232_0: The training rule on private and concealed
tika-vin04t0:233_0: If a monk sits down in private on a concealed seat with a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:234_0: The training rule on sitting in private,
tika-vin04t0:235_0: If a monk sits down in private alone with a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:237_1: If a monk who has been invited to a meal visits families beforehand or afterwards without taking leave of an available monk, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:237_2: This is the appropriate occasion: it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes; he is traveling.’”
tika-vin04t0:239_1: A monk who is not sick may accept an invitation to ask for requisites for four months. They may accept a permanent invitation, except if it is.
tika-vin04t0:239_2: If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:240_0: The training rule on armies in action
tika-vin04t0:241_0: Then a monk who is committed to see the army in action, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:242_0: The training rule on staying with armies
tika-vin04t0:243_1: If that monk has a reason for going to the army, he may stay with the army for two or three nights.
tika-vin04t0:243_2: If he stays longer than that, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:245_1: If a monk who is staying with an army for two or three nights goes to a battle, a troop review, a massing of the army, or a troop inspection, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:246_0: The fifth sub-chapter on naked ascetics is finished.
tika-vin04t0:247_0: The training rule on drinking alcoholic drinks
tika-vin04t0:248_0: against the stream, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:24_1: If a monk, intending to steal, takes from a village or wilderness, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth, or belonging to the community of bandits, that bandits, arrested a fool, a thief, or a thief. This too is too tall.
tika-vin04t0:250_0: If he tickles another with their fingers, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:252_0: If he plays in water, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:254_0: and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:256_0: If a monk takes hold of him, contacts him, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:258_1: If a monk who is not sick lights a fire to warm himself, or has one lit, except if there is an suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:260_1: ‘If a monk bathes at intervals of less than a half-month, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:260_2: These are the appropriate occasions: ‘Currently this is the two-and-a-half months of summer, so that is the first month of the rainy season; he is sick; it is working; he is traveling; there is wind and rain.’”
tika-vin04t0:261_0: The training rule on making stains,
tika-vin04t0:262_1: A monk should apply one of three kinds of stain: blue-green, mud-color, or dark brown.
tika-vin04t0:262_2: If a monk uses a new robe without applying any of the three kinds of stain, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:263_0: The training rule on transferring to another
tika-vin04t0:264_1: If a monk himself transfers a robe to a monk, to a nun, to a trainee nun, to a novice monk, or to a novice nun, and he then uses it without it first being relinquished, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:265_0: The training rule on not standing
tika-vin04t0:266_1: If a monk hides a monk’s bowl, robe, sitting mat, needle case, or belt, or he has it hidden, even if just for a laugh, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:267_0: The sixth sub-chapter on drinking alcohol is finished.
tika-vin04t0:269_0: But if a monk intentionally kills a living being, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:26_1: If a monk intentionally kills a human being or seeks an instrument of death for him; or he praises death or incites someone to die, saying, ‘This is good and bad.’ But if he kills you in many ways, that’s better than an expelled and excluded from the community.
tika-vin04t0:270_0: The training rule on containing living beings
tika-vin04t0:271_0: If a monk uses water that he knows contains living beings, and he knows that he has, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:273_0: If a monk reopens a legal issue, then that legal issue has been legitimately settled, that he knows was reopened, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:274_0: The training rule on what is grave
tika-vin04t0:275_0: If a monk knowingly conceals a monk’s grave offense, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:276_0: The training rule on less than twenty years old
tika-vin04t0:277_1: But if a monk gives the full ordination to a person he knows is less than twenty years old, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:278_0: The training rule on a group of traveling thieves
tika-vin04t0:279_1: If a monk knowingly travels by appointment with a group of thieves, even just to the next village, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:27_0: The training rule on superhuman quality
tika-vin04t0:280_0: The training rule on being inspired
tika-vin04t0:281_1: If a monk travels by appointment with a woman, even just to the next village, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:283_1: But when a mendicant says that the Buddha has taught like this, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them. And that would not be obstructed by the Buddha, and the mendicants do not really obstructions for the one who performs them.
tika-vin04t0:283_2: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view.
tika-vin04t0:283_3: If he then gives it up, all is well.
tika-vin04t0:283_4: If he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:284_0: The training rule on living with one who has been ejected
tika-vin04t0:285_1: If a monk lives, does formal meetings, or shares a sleeping place with a monk whom he knows is saying such things, who has not made amends according to the rule, and who has not given up that view, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:287_1: If even a novice monk says, ‘I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the mendicants do not obstruct the one who performs them. But for the sake of obstructions, the monks should say that they don’t obstruct the one who acts had spoken by the Buddha, and that novice nun.
tika-vin04t0:287_2: If a monk supports that novice monastic, or he is attended on by him, lives with him, or shares a sleeping place with him, even though he knows that he has been expelled in this way, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:288_0: The seventh sub-chapter on containing living beings is finished.
tika-vin04t0:28_1: If a monk, without exception of a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, so they think: ‘I know and see.’ Not seeing, they say, ‘I see.’ So let them fulfill their knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, it’s for them to be expelled and excluded from the community. The training rule on asking me,
tika-vin04t0:290_1: If a monk, when legitimately corrected by the monks, says, “I won’t practice this training rule until I’ve questioned a monk who is an expert on the Monastic Law,” he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:290_2: A monk who is training should understand, should question, should enquire.
tika-vin04t0:291_0: The training rule on digging the pretext
tika-vin04t0:292_1: Or when the Monastic Code is being recited, if a monk says, “This is the point of reciting these minor and insignificant training rules, when they just lead to anxiety, oppression, and annoyance?” then in disparaging the training rules, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:294_1: Or if a monk recites the Monastic Code, having recited the Monastic Code, having concluded their path after reciting it, that this rule too has come down in the Monastic Code, is included in the Monastic Code, and comes up for recitation every half-month.’
tika-vin04t0:294_2: If other monks know that that monk has previously sat through at least two or three recitations of the Monastic Code, then that monk is not let off because of ignorance, and he is to be dealt with according to the rule. Further, he should be charged with deception:
tika-vin04t0:296_0: If a monk hits a monk in anger, he hits him with the intention of getting it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:297_0: The training rule on raising a hand
tika-vin04t0:298_0: If a monk raises a hand in anger against his hand, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:29_0: “Venerables, the four rules on expulsion have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:29_1: If a monk commits any one of them, he no longer belongs to the community of monks. As before, so after, he is expelled and excluded from the community.
tika-vin04t0:29_2: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:300_0: When a monk groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing suspension, he commits one offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:302_1: If a monk intentionally makes a monk anxious, thinking, “In this way he will be ill at ease at least for a moment,” and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:304_1: If a monk eavesdrops on monks who are arguing and disputing, thinking, “I’ll hear what they say,” and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:305_0: The training rule on obstructing a legal procedure
tika-vin04t0:306_0: When a monk has given his consent to legitimate legal procedures, and then criticizes them afterwards, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:307_0: The training rule on leaving without giving consent
tika-vin04t0:308_1: When the Sangha is in the process of deliberating, if a monk gets up from his seat and leaves without first giving his consent, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:309_0: The training rule on what is worn out
tika-vin04t0:30_0: The offenses entailing expulsion are finished.
tika-vin04t0:310_1: If a monk gives out a robe as part of a unanimous Sangha and then criticizes it afterwards, saying, “The monks are diverting the Sangha’s material gains according to friendship,” he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:312_0: If a monk diverts to an individual material support that he knows was intended for the Sangha, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:313_0: The eighth sub-chapter on legitimately is finished.
tika-vin04t0:314_0: The training rule on royal compounds
tika-vin04t0:315_1: If a monk, without first being announced, crosses the threshold to the bedroom of a consecrated aristocrat king, when both the king and the queen are present, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:316_0: The training rule on precious things
tika-vin04t0:317_1: If a monk picks up something precious or something regarded as precious, or he has it picked up, except within a monastery or inside a lodging, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:317_2: If he picks up something precious or something regarded as precious, or he has it picked up, within a monastery or inside a lodging, he should put it aside with the thought, “Whoever owns it will fetch it.” This is the proper procedure.’
tika-vin04t0:318_0: The training rule on entering an inhabited area at the wrong time,
tika-vin04t0:319_1: If a monk, when another monk is available, enters an inhabited area at the wrong time without taking leave of him, except if there is some appropriate urgent business, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:320_0: The training rule on needle cases
tika-vin04t0:321_1: If a monk has a needle case made from bone, ivory, or horn, it is to be destroyed, and he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:322_0: The training rule on beds and benches
tika-vin04t0:323_1: If a monk is having a new bed or bench made, it is to have legs eight standard fingerbreadths long below the lowest frame.
tika-vin04t0:323_2: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:324_0: The training rule on upholstered with cotton down,
tika-vin04t0:325_0: If a monk makes a bed or a bench made upholstered with cotton down, it is to be stripped, and he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:326_0: The training rule on sitting mats
tika-vin04t0:327_1: ‘There are a monk made: if it is the right size, he may be made for two standard handspans long and one handspans long and two wide.
tika-vin04t0:327_2: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:328_0: The training rule on itch covers
tika-vin04t0:329_1: ‘If a monk is having an itch-covering cloth made, it should be made the right size: four standard handspans long and one-and-a-half wide.’”
tika-vin04t0:329_2: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:330_0: The training rule on rainy-season robes
tika-vin04t0:331_1: ‘If a monk is having a rainy-season robe made, it should be made the right size: six standard handspans long and six wide.’”
tika-vin04t0:331_2: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:333_1: If a monk has a robe made that is the standard robe measure or larger, it is to be cut down, and he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:333_2: This is the standard robe measure: nine standard handspans long and six wide.’”
tika-vin04t0:334_0: The ninth sub-chapter on precious things is finished.
tika-vin04t0:335_0: “Venerables, the ninety-two rules on confession have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:335_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:336_0: The section on confession is finished.
tika-vin04t0:338_0: Venerables, these four rules on acknowledgment
tika-vin04t0:340_0: The first training rule on acknowledgment
tika-vin04t0:341_1: ‘If a monk receives staple or non-staple food directly from an unrelated nun who has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he must acknowledge it:
tika-vin04t0:342_0: The second training rule on acknowledgment
tika-vin04t0:343_1: If monks eat at invitations to families, if a nun is there giving directions, saying, “Give bean curry here; give rice here,” then give her this rice.’
tika-vin04t0:343_2: Those monks should stop her: ‘Stop, Sister, while the monks are eating’:
tika-vin04t0:343_3: a monk shouldn’t rebuke even criticism by a nun who said to her, “Sister, while those monks are still lightly,” then they should acknowledge it. And while those monks are eating, making a loose.
tika-vin04t0:344_0: The third training rule on acknowledgment
tika-vin04t0:345_1: ‘There are families that are designated as “in training”. If a monk, without being sick and without first being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, he must acknowledge it: “You should acknowledge it: this is the offense.’ Then he must acknowledge it:
tika-vin04t0:346_0: The fourth training rule on acknowledgment
tika-vin04t0:347_1: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. If a monk who is not sick, without first making an announcement about those dwellings, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, he should acknowledge it:
tika-vin04t0:348_0: “Venerables, the four rules on acknowledgment have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:348_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:349_0: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment is finished.
tika-vin04t0:34_0: The training rule on emission of semen
tika-vin04t0:351_0: Venerables, these rules to be trained in come up for recitation.
tika-vin04t0:352_0: The training rule on evenly all around,
tika-vin04t0:353_0: I will put up my knees,
tika-vin04t0:354_0: I will wear my sarong evenly all around,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:356_0: One should be well-covered while walking in an inhabited area,
tika-vin04t0:357_0: One should be well-covered while sitting in an inhabited area,
tika-vin04t0:359_0: he should train himself well-restrained in inhabited areas,
tika-vin04t0:35_0: and while dreaming, they are an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:360_0: One should sit well-restrained in an inhabited area,
tika-vin04t0:361_0: The training rule on lowered eyes
tika-vin04t0:362_0: One should lower one’s eyes while walking in an inhabited area, that is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:363_0: One should lower one’s eyes while sitting in an inhabited area, that is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:364_0: The training rule on lifted robe
tika-vin04t0:365_0: I will lift my robe while walking in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:366_0: I will lift my robe while sitting in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:367_0: The first sub-chapter on evenly all around is finished.
tika-vin04t0:368_0: The training rule on laughing loudly,
tika-vin04t0:369_0: One should not laugh loudly while walking in an inhabited area, but this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:36_0: The training rule on physical contact
tika-vin04t0:370_0: One should not laugh loudly while sitting in an inhabited area, but this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:371_0: The training rule on loud noises
tika-vin04t0:372_0: he should train himself while walking in inhabited areas,
tika-vin04t0:373_0: he should train himself while sitting in inhabited areas;
tika-vin04t0:374_0: The training rule on swaying the body
tika-vin04t0:375_0: One should not sway one’s body while walking in an inhabited area, this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:376_0: One should not sway one’s body while sitting in an inhabited area, but this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:377_0: The training rule on swinging the arms
tika-vin04t0:378_0: I will swing my arms while walking in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:379_0: One should not swing one’s arms while sitting in an inhabited area, but this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:37_1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, makes physical contact with a woman—holding her hand or hair, or touching any part of her body—he commits an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:380_0: The training rule on swaying the head
tika-vin04t0:381_0: he should not sway his head while walking in inhabited areas,
tika-vin04t0:382_0: he should not sway his head while sitting in inhabited areas; he should train his head:
tika-vin04t0:383_0: The second sub-chapter on laughing loudly is finished.
tika-vin04t0:384_0: The training rule on arms akimbo
tika-vin04t0:385_0: I will not lift my robe while walking in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:386_0: he should not sit with arms akimbo in inhabited areas,
tika-vin04t0:387_0: The training rule on covering the head
tika-vin04t0:388_0: I will not cover my head while walking in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:389_0: One should not cover one’s head while sitting in an inhabited area, but this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:38_0: The training rule on indecent speech
tika-vin04t0:390_0: The training rule on squatting on the heels,
tika-vin04t0:391_0: I will not squat on my heels while walking in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:392_0: The training rule on clasping the knees
tika-vin04t0:393_0: he should not clasp his knees while sitting in inhabited areas,
tika-vin04t0:394_0: The training rule on receiving respectfully
tika-vin04t0:396_0: The training rule on receiving with attention on the almsbowl
tika-vin04t0:397_0: If he receives almsfood, but he perceives him as such, and he receives it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:398_0: The training rule on receiving an even measure of bean curry
tika-vin04t0:399_0: I will receive almsfood with the right proportion of bean curry,
tika-vin04t0:39_1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, speaks indecent words connected with sexual intercourse to a woman, as a young man might to a young woman, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:400_0: The training rule on even levels
tika-vin04t0:401_0: If he receives almsfood with the intention of eating it, he should train it:
tika-vin04t0:402_0: The third sub-chapter on arms akimbo is finished.
tika-vin04t0:403_0: The rule, the training rule on eating,
tika-vin04t0:405_0: The training rule on eating with attention on the almsbowl,
tika-vin04t0:406_0: If he is eating his bowl and robe, but he perceives that he has, then that is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:408_0: If he eats almsfood with himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:409_0: The training rule on an even measure of bean curry
tika-vin04t0:40_0: The training rule on satisfying one’s own desires
tika-vin04t0:410_0: this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:411_0: The training rule on what is shaped
tika-vin04t0:412_0: I will eat almsfood picking from a heap, but there is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:413_0: The training rule on covering with rice
tika-vin04t0:414_0: I will cover my curries with rice because I want more.
tika-vin04t0:415_0: The training rule on asking for rice and bean curry
tika-vin04t0:416_0: If he is not sick, but having asked for bean curry or rice for himself and then eat it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:417_0: The training rule on finding fault
tika-vin04t0:418_0: One should not look at the bowl of another finding fault, but he perceives another’s bowl to others,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:419_0: The training rule on mouthfuls that are too large,
tika-vin04t0:41_1: If a monk, overcome by lust and with a distorted mind, encourages a woman to satisfy his own desires: “Sister, she provides the highest service who in this way satisfies one like me, who is virtuous, celibate, and of good character,” and if it is a reference to sexual intercourse, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’
tika-vin04t0:420_0: I will not make a mouthful that’s too large,
tika-vin04t0:422_0: If he makes a mouthful that’s too large, then this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:423_0: The fourth sub-chapter on respectfully is finished.
tika-vin04t0:424_0: The training rule on without bringing
tika-vin04t0:425_0: I will open my mouth without bringing a mouthful to it,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:427_0: I will put down my whole body, but only in front of all around,’ this is how you should train.”
tika-vin04t0:428_0: The training rule on with a mouthful
tika-vin04t0:429_0: this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:430_0: The training rule on lifted balls of food
tika-vin04t0:431_0: I will eat from a lifted ball of food, but this is how you should train.”
tika-vin04t0:432_0: The training rule on breaking up balls of food
tika-vin04t0:433_0: I will not eat breaking up a ball of food, this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:434_0: The training rule on stuffing the cheeks
tika-vin04t0:435_0: If he doesn’t eat too much, but only when asked.
tika-vin04t0:436_0: The training rule on shaking the hand
tika-vin04t0:437_0: I will not eat shaking my hand,
tika-vin04t0:438_0: The training rule on scattering rice
tika-vin04t0:439_0: he should eat scattering rice about;
tika-vin04t0:43_1: If a monk acts as a matchmaker, conveying a man’s intentions to a woman or a woman’s intentions to a man, for marriage or for an affair, even if only a lay person wishes.
tika-vin04t0:440_0: The training rule on sticking out the tongue
tika-vin04t0:441_0: But I will not eat sticking out my tongue,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:442_0: The training rule on chomping sounds
tika-vin04t0:443_0: I will not make a chomping sound while eating,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:444_0: The fifth sub-chapter on mouthfuls is finished.
tika-vin04t0:446_0: I will not slurp while eating,
tika-vin04t0:447_0: The training rule on licking the hands
tika-vin04t0:448_0: he should not eat licking his hands;
tika-vin04t0:449_0: The training rule on licking the almsbowl
tika-vin04t0:44_0: The training rule on building huts
tika-vin04t0:450_0: he should not eat licking his bowl;
tika-vin04t0:451_0: The training rule on licking the lips
tika-vin04t0:452_0: I will eat too much, but there is no needle case.
tika-vin04t0:453_0: The training rule on with food
tika-vin04t0:454_0: I will not receive the drinking-water vessel with a hand soiled with food,
tika-vin04t0:455_0: The training rule on containing rice
tika-vin04t0:456_0: ‘I will not discard bowl-washing water containing rice in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.’
tika-vin04t0:457_0: The training rule on holding a sunshade
tika-vin04t0:458_0: If you don’t give a teaching to anyone holding a sunshade who is not sick, I will train.
tika-vin04t0:459_0: The training rule on holding a staff
tika-vin04t0:45_1: ‘When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself, it is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long and seven wide inside.
tika-vin04t0:45_2: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks a space on all sides, or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the right size, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:460_0: One should not give a teaching to anyone holding a staff who is not sick, and who is unsure of it,
tika-vin04t0:461_0: The training rule on holding a knife,
tika-vin04t0:462_0: If you give a teaching to anyone holding a knife who is not sick, I will train.
tika-vin04t0:463_0: The training rule on holding a weapon
tika-vin04t0:464_0: If you give a teaching to anyone holding a weapon who is not sick, I will train in the same way.’
tika-vin04t0:465_0: The sixth sub-chapter on slurping is finished.
tika-vin04t0:467_0: If you’re not sick, I will give a teaching to anyone wearing shoes who is not sick,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:469_0: If you don’t give a teaching to anyone wearing sandals who is not sick, you should train.
tika-vin04t0:46_0: The training rule on building dwellings
tika-vin04t0:470_0: The training rule on asking for
tika-vin04t0:471_0: If you’re not sick, I will give a teaching to anyone in a vehicle who is not sick,’ this is how you should train.
tika-vin04t0:472_0: The training rule on lying down
tika-vin04t0:473_0: If you’re not sick, I will give a teaching to anyone lying down, and you should train like this:
tika-vin04t0:474_0: The training rule on clasping the knees
tika-vin04t0:475_0: If you don’t give a teaching to anyone who is seated clasping their knees, you should train.
tika-vin04t0:477_0: If you don’t give a teaching to anyone wearing a headdress who is not sick, you should train yourselves like this: ‘I will not give a teaching.’
tika-vin04t0:478_0: The training rule on covering the head
tika-vin04t0:479_0: If you’re not sick, but you should give a teaching to anyone with a covered head who is not sick, I will train.
tika-vin04t0:47_1: ‘When a monk builds a large dwelling with a sponsoring owner and intended for himself, he may confess a space on all sides.
tika-vin04t0:47_2: If a monk builds a large dwelling on a site where harm will be done and which lacks a space on all sides, or he does not get monks to approve the site, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:480_0: The training rule on the ground
tika-vin04t0:481_0: sitting on the ground, I will not give a teaching while sitting on the ground to anyone sitting on a seat who is not sick,
tika-vin04t0:482_0: The training rule on low seats,
tika-vin04t0:483_0: while sitting on a low seat to someone sitting on a high seat who is not sick, I will train his people sitting on a high seat.
tika-vin04t0:485_0: If you’re not sick, but you should give a teaching while standing to anyone sitting who is not sick, I will train.
tika-vin04t0:486_0: The training rule on walking behind
tika-vin04t0:487_0: If you don’t give a teaching while walking behind to someone walking in front who is not sick, you should train in front of them:
tika-vin04t0:488_0: The training rule on walking off the path
tika-vin04t0:489_0: If you’re not sick, but you should give a teaching while walking next to the path to anyone walking on the path who is not sick, you should train.
tika-vin04t0:491_0: If one who is not sick defecates, urinates, or defecates, and urinates while standing, this is how you should train.’
tika-vin04t0:492_0: The training rule on defecating on cultivated plants
tika-vin04t0:493_0: If one is not sick, but should not defecate, urinate, or spit on cultivated plants, that is how you should train.’
tika-vin04t0:494_0: The training rule on defecating in water
tika-vin04t0:495_0: If one is not sick, one should not defecate, urinate, or spit in water, or spit in the water.
tika-vin04t0:496_0: The seventh sub-chapter on shoes is finished.
tika-vin04t0:497_0: “Venerables, the rules to be trained in have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:497_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:498_0: The rules to be trained in are finished.
tika-vin04t0:49_1: If a monk who is angry and displeased groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, but groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing suspension, both the rule and the summaries of that legal issue is groundless, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
tika-vin04t0:4_0: The water dragged light, and the water flames
tika-vin04t0:500_0: Venerables, these seven principles for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.
tika-vin04t0:502_0: Removal in the presence of those concerned is applicable.
tika-vin04t0:503_0: removal by accurate recollection is applicable to them.
tika-vin04t0:504_0: Removal in resolution because of past insanity is applicable.
tika-vin04t0:507_0: by a verdict of aggravated misconduct.
tika-vin04t0:509_0: Venerables, the seven principles for the settling of legal issues have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:509_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:50_0: The training rule on evasive speech
tika-vin04t0:510_0: The section for recitation on the disciplinary issues are finished.
tika-vin04t0:512_0: the four rules on expulsion have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:513_0: the thirteen rules on suspension have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:514_0: the two undetermined rules have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:515_0: the thirty rules on relinquishment and confession have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:516_0: the ninety-two rules on confession have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:517_0: the four rules on acknowledgment have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:518_0: the rules to be trained in have been recited;
tika-vin04t0:519_0: Venerables, the seven principles for the settling of legal issues have been recited and heard in accordance with the Buddha, the recitation of the Monastic Code, and in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling.
tika-vin04t0:51_1: If a monk who is angry and displeased, using an unrelated legal issue as a pretext, charges a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make him leave the monastic life, and an unrelated legal issue then applying that legal issue is unrelated to an offense. Then—this is called “legitimately”.
tika-vin04t0:520_0: In full ordination, there are five training rules for recitation.
tika-vin04t0:521_0: The group of monks is finished.
tika-vin04t0:522_0: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
tika-vin04t0:52_0: The training rule on schism in the Sangha
tika-vin04t0:53_1: If a monk pursues schism in a united Sangha or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the monks should press him, and bring up that legal issue by the schism, then if it is unity, the Sangha, the monks should press him, and make an effort to endeaves. If he does not stop, then the view after giving up that view, the full ordination, the wholesometic, or the Sangha would carefully pursue this view: ‘The Sangha bring it to one another monk in harmony.’
tika-vin04t0:54_0: The training rule on supporting a schism
tika-vin04t0:55_1: If the monks keep on instructing that monk
tika-vin04t0:56_0: The training rule on being difficult to correct
tika-vin04t0:57_1: If a monk is difficult to correct, and he makes himself incorrigible. If he is legitimately corrected by the monks concerning one another, and the monks should correct him like this: ‘That’s good monks,’ and if they are legitimately corrected by me,’ and it is beneficial, then that monk should be legitimately.
tika-vin04t0:58_0: The training rule on corrupters of families
tika-vin04t0:59_1: ‘If a monk lives supported by a village or town, and a bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and bad behavior; and his families corrupted by him have been seen and heard about, and the monks from that monastery, his bad behavior will make amends. And now they say, “You’re not seen, heard, thought, or known something, and they have heard about this.
tika-vin04t0:5_0: the observance day, and we speak of ‘fallend’.
tika-vin04t0:60_0: “Venerables, the thirteen rules on suspension have been recited, nine being immediate offenses, four after the third announcement.
tika-vin04t0:60_1: If a monk commits any one of them, he is to undergo probation for the same number of days as he knowingly concealed that offense.
tika-vin04t0:60_2: When this is completed, he must undertake the trial period for a further six days. He should then wipe that monk.
tika-vin04t0:60_3: If that monk is rehabilitated by an Sangha of even one less than twenty, that monk is not rehabilitated and those monks are at fault. This is the proper procedure.
tika-vin04t0:60_4: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’
tika-vin04t0:61_0: The second offense entailing suspension is finished.
tika-vin04t0:66_1: If a monk sits down in private on a concealed seat suitable for action, and he admits to a woman, and he admits to a trustworthy female lay person, saying,
tika-vin04t0:68_1: If a monk is not concealed for action, but he does not suitable to sit down in private on a concealed seat suitable for action, and he admits to a woman, or he admits to an offense entailing suspension, he commits two offenses entailing confession.
tika-vin04t0:69_0: “Venerables, the two undetermined rules have been recited.
tika-vin04t0:69_1: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this matter, I hope you’ll ask for a third time. I hope you will remember it thus.’

tika-vin04t0:72_0: Venerables, these thirty rules on relinquishment and confession have been recited
tika-vin04t0:74_0: The training rule on the robe-making season
tika-vin04t0:75_1: When his robe is finished and the robe-making season has ended, if he keeps it for ten days at the most, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:76_0: The rule, the training rule on stored,
tika-vin04t0:77_1: When his robe is finished and the robe-making season has ended, if a monk stays apart from his three robes even for a single day, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:78_0: The training rule on out-of-season robe-cloth
tika-vin04t0:79_1: When his robe is finished and the robe-making season has ended, if out-of-season robe-cloth is given to a monk, he may receive it if he wishes, if it is to be received at most, he should keep it over that robe.
tika-vin04t0:79_2: If he keeps it beyond that, even if he expects more cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:7_0: For the instruction, the consent of the group, and the Sangha of nuns;
tika-vin04t0:80_0: The training rule on used robes
tika-vin04t0:81_1: If a monk gets an unrelated nun to wash, dye, or beat a used robe, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:82_0: The training rule on receiving robe-cloth
tika-vin04t0:83_1: If a monk receives a robe directly from an unrelated nun, except if it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:84_0: The training rule on asking non-relations
tika-vin04t0:85_1: If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:85_2: This is the appropriate occasion: his robes are stolen or his robes are destroyed.’”
tika-vin04t0:86_0: The training rule on more than that
tika-vin04t0:87_1: If the housewife Nakula’s father invites that monk to take many robes, he should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe.
tika-vin04t0:87_2: If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:88_0: The first rule, the training rule on what is set aside,
tika-vin04t0:89_1: If a monk borrowed robes to a householder or householder’s robe fund, for a robe fund, for a monk so-and-som, without first being invited, let him buy, saying, “Buy a robe fund for me, I’ll buy something to buy,” and he says, “It’s good,” “I’ll buy this robe fund it,” “I’ll buy separately,” he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:8_0: to the observance day, they are called ‘one who makes an observance day’.
tika-vin04t0:90_0: The second training rule on what is set aside
tika-vin04t0:91_1: If two male or female householders have set aside separate robe funds for an unrelated monk, but having invited them to buy robes and specifies, saying, “In this way we’ll buy robes; we’ll buy robes with these separate robes, if they wanted water to borrow them, and he says, ‘If only for this robe, we’ll buy it.’
tika-vin04t0:93_1: a king’s employee, a brahmin, or a householder sends a robe fund for a monk so-and-so. Then he sends a robe fund to so-and-so.’
tika-vin04t0:93_2: If that messenger goes to that monk and says, “Venerable, please accept a robe fund for you,”
tika-vin04t0:93_3: That monk should tell that messenger to accept a robe, but we do receive allowable robes at the right time.’
tika-vin04t0:93_4: and that messenger goes to that monk. Please correct him, make an offering him a deliver.’
tika-vin04t0:93_5: A monk should provide services for a monastery worker, either a lay follower, or a monastery worker. He should think, ‘There is a monk.’
tika-vin04t0:93_6: If that messenger goes to the next monk, but he must tell them to persuade him, ‘Venerable, they’d give him a service, and they can send you a robe, saying, ‘Venerable, please give me a robe,’
tika-vin04t0:93_7: If he then gets a robe, all is well. If he accuses him, saying, ‘If he then gets a robe, he should stand in silence for him, and he does so just six times.
tika-vin04t0:93_8: If he does not get a robe, he should go to the owners of that robe fund, or send a message: ʻIndeed, he should go to that monk, even if he sends him away, saying, “Rejoice, this monk shouldn’t give him a robe.’
tika-vin04t0:94_0: The first sub-chapter on the robe-making season is finished.
tika-vin04t0:96_0: If a monk has one blanket made that contains silk, he has a blanket made, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
tika-vin04t0:97_0: The training rule on entirely black
tika-vin04t0:98_0: If a monk has a blanket made entirely of black wool, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
